column11: Following the debacle with Robodebt , I am concerned if law enforcement relies on AI. However I believe that government should complement with review by humans.

column11: I don't believe that there is sufficient transparency in how Australian police and security are allowed to use AI in their operations. Even if it was sufficiently transparent (according both to law and public interest), I'm not confident that this information would be user-friendly. The use of AI as a predictive technology for law enforcement purposes is still significantly under-defined, which leaves open many opportunities for abuse and misuse. Obviously this is bad for citizens (and also law enforcement & security agents themselves, who are often forgotten in this debate) but it also means that any genuinely good outcomes that might come of its use (e.g. intercepting organised crime) can be negated or reversed later in court, when laws and regulations mature.
column28: Big data distillation to recognise patterns of illegal activity.
column29: Transparency, accountability, integration of LE use of AI into legal procedures (if these systems aren't harmonized what's the point)
column30: Cutting edge technical privacy & encryption standards (which get extremely close to genuine de-identification), widespread and high quality education about how AI works and how it can/should be used (training delivered to LE/security, which would be accountable to an education body like TEQSA), restriction of AI use to quantitative problems (e.g. processing details of arrests in order to accurately count number of arrest types within a time period)
